p: Despite this pioneering research, the impacts of climate change and human activities on ecological networks remain poorly understood, especially with respect to the human impact on pollination networks. Moreover, macro-ecological studies [ 28, 31, 32] have overwhelmingly focused on the impacts of climate change and human activities on mutualistic networks (i.e., pollination and seed-dispersal networks), and not food webs, for which there has been comparatively little research (e.g., the effect of human activities on preyâ€“predator interactions at a local scale [ 33] and over a broader marine region [ 34]).
